summary: Skin cancer is a type of cancer that arises from the skin cells, characterized by the uncontrolled growth of abnormal cells that can invade or spread to other parts of the body. It is the most common form of cancer globally. The primary cause is prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun or tanning devices, which damages skin cell DNA. There are three main types: basal-cell skin cancer (BCC), squamous-cell skin cancer (SCC), and melanoma. BCC and SCC are collectively known as nonmelanoma skin cancer (NMSC). BCC typically grows slowly and rarely spreads, while SCC is more likely to spread. Melanoma is the most aggressive and dangerous type. Diagnosis is usually made by biopsy and histopathological examination. Treatment depends on the type, location, and stage of the cancer, and commonly involves surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, photodynamic therapy, and biologic therapy.
causes: Prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun
Exposure to UV radiation from tanning devices
UVB radiation via direct DNA damage (for BCC and SCC)
UVA radiation via indirect DNA damage (for melanoma)
HPV infections (increase risk of squamous-cell skin cancer)
Deliberate exposure of sensitive skin to sunlight
risk_factors: Spending a lot of time in the sun
Poor immune function (e.g., from medications or HIV/AIDS)
Having moles (especially larger ones or those that change)
Ozone depletion (contributes to increased UV exposure)
symptoms: Changes in the skin that do not heal
Changes in existing moles (size, shape, color, irregular edges, bleeding, itching)
Painful lesion that itches or burns
Large brownish spot with darker speckles
Raised, smooth, pearly bump on sun-exposed skin (BCC)
Small blood vessels visible within the tumor (BCC)
Crusting and bleeding in the center of the tumor (BCC)
Red, scaling, thickened patch on sun-exposed skin (SCC)
Firm hard nodules with scaly top (SCC)
Various colors from shades of brown to black (melanoma)
Pink, red, or fleshy colored moles (amelanotic melanoma)
Rapidly growing, non-tender red, purple, or skin-colored bumps (Merkel cell carcinomas)
treatments: Targeted therapy (e.g., BRAF inhibitors, MEK inhibitors)
subtypes: Skin sarcomas (e.g., angiosarcoma, dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans, Kaposi's sarcoma, leiomyosarcoma)
